info.game_comments:
2004-A Kids Week game 3.
From Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: In October 1723 Franklin arrived in this city that would be his home base for the rest of his life

(3, 1).clue: Tucson, the second-largest city in this state, is about 100 miles south of its largest city, Phoenix

(4, 1).clue: In this game, an entry sport to baseball, the batter hits the ball that rests atop a tube

(5, 1).clue: Have your mom cut your carrots into these for your lunchbox & you can play a "pick up" game with them

(1, 2).clue: Ben Franklin, on top of things as always, suggested this seasonal clock change system back in 1784

(3, 2).clue: The South Side of this city is where the White Sox call home

(4, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew strolls down the lane at the Nat'l Bowling Stadium in Reno, NV--& screws up.) Oops--in bowling, it's the one place you don't wanna throw your ball

(5, 2).clue: A man named Mel Blanc crunched carrots while providing the voice of this carrot-loving rabbit

(6, 2).clue: A feat or exploit; usually a praiseworthy act

(1, 3).clue: In 1744 Franklin was really cookin' when he invented a cast-iron one of these that you could install in your fireplace

(3, 3).clue: The region of Calabria occupies the "toe" of this nation; Apulia, the "heel" (& Tuscany, the thigh)

(4, 3).clue: It's the sport played professionally by Andre Agassi

(5, 3).clue: In February 1999 people in Bethel, Maine made one 113 feet tall with an 8-foot-long "carrot" nose

(6, 3).clue: This term refers to a bomb or explosive that fails to detonate

(1, 4).clue: Joseph Priestley was so "charged" after meeting Ben, he wrote "The History and Present State of" this phenomenon

(3, 4).clue: Wallabies & wombats abound in the state called "South" this country

(4, 4).clue: What the Europeans call association football, we call this

(5, 4).clue: This popular dessert is usually topped with a cream cheese frosting

(6, 4).clue: "Wiener Dogs on Parade", featuring this breed, is a part of Ashland, Oregon's annual 4th of July parade

(3, 5).clue: Oslo is in the south of this country whose north is above the Arctic circle

(4, 5).clue: In golf it's the proper word to yell when your ball is headed toward another player

(5, 5).clue: Carrots go into one version of this side dish, shredded cabbage & a mayonnaise-based sauce

(6, 5).clue: This shepherd's name appears more than 1,000 times in the Old & New Testaments

(1, 1).clue: He's "You-know-who", the evil wizard, "He-who-must-not-be-named" in the Harry Potter books

(2, 1).clue: It's the board game in which you could be ordered to "Go directly to jail, do not pass go, do not collect $200"

(3, 1).clue: Ratified in 1971, the 26th amendment to the Constitution lowered the voting age to this

(4, 1).clue: First off, maybe you & Mom should get a comfortable pair of sneakers from the "Kids" & "Lady" divisions of this store

(5, 1).clue: After moving to Spain in 1485 he used Colon, the Spanish version of his name

(6, 1).clue: The word hankie is short for this; now wipe your nose

(1, 2).clue: A favorite of early readers, he's the beloved oversized pet seen here

(2, 2).clue: It's the popular game invented in 1948, and what do you mean "Trebek" isn't allowed?

(3, 2).clue: With 53 congressmen, this state has more representatives in the house than any other

(4, 2).clue: For lunch, drop by the Rainforest Cafe or grab a Whopper from this fast food chain

(5, 2).clue: In May 1953 Edmund Hillary was on top of the world, or at least on top of this highest mountain

(6, 2).clue: Rearrange the letters in adobe to come up with this word for a home

(1, 3).clue: With a little imagination & his purple crayon, he can go anywhere: the circus, even outer space

(2, 3).clue: In this "Checkers" game, the board is a 6-pointed star, & every player starts with 10 marbles

(3, 3).clue: A plow is depicted on the seal of this cabinet department created in 1862

(4, 3).clue: At Cereal Adventure, you'll go cuckoo for the Chocolate Canyon attraction named for this cereal

(5, 3).clue: Falsely accused of treason, this discoverer of the Pacific Ocean was beheaded in 1519

(6, 3).clue: Pronounced one way, it's an injury; pronounced another, it can mean turned & tightened, like certain clocks

(1, 4).clue: A monkey named Mr. Nilsson often rides on the shoulder of this freckle-faced orphan with crazy red pigtails

(2, 4).clue: The object of this game with a 4-letter name is to occupy every country & thus conquer the world

(3, 4).clue: In 1917 the people of this U.S. commonwealth in the Caribbean became naturalized citizens

(5, 4).clue: In 1514 this explorer received a royal commission to colonize Florida

(6, 4).clue: It can mean to scrape the surface of the skin, or to feed out in the pasture

(1, 5).clue: Felicity, a Colonial lass, & Addy, who escaped slavery, are 2 of the delightful females in this book series

(2, 5).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reads before she plays a fast game of chess with Jimmy.) We've only got 5 minutes each to make all our moves in this game with a two-word name

(3, 5).clue: The Supreme Court has a Chief Justice & this many associate justices

(5, 5).clue: Yes, Sir!  This Englishman seen here, who completed a round-the-world voyage, was knighted in 1581

(6, 5).clue: Spelled differenty, it can be a daisy, or a baking ingredient

(0, 0).clue: A 35-foot-long muslin stocking was used to create the cyclone for this 1939 film
